DOC.HEAD: Judge's Funeral Held Under Tight Security
Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 9th graf pvs, `Family friends ...' with comment from NAACP's Hooks.
DOC.TEXT: Bomb-sniffing dogs and dozens of police provided security today at the funeral of a federal judge killed by a parcel bomb in a wave of attacks that may have been carried out by white racists. More than 700 mourners, including Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and FBI Director William S. Sessions, filled a suburban church for the service in memory of U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance. Vance was a man ``who stood up for the underdog and the oppressed,'' his friend U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Clifford Fulford of Birmingham told mourners. ``No wonder his assassins could not stand such a man in their presence.'' The 58-year-old Vance was killed by a package bomb Saturday. FBI agents say the bomb and three others, including the one that killed Savannah, Ga., lawyer Robert Robinson, 42, on Monday, all bore Georgia return addresses or postmarks. Links to NAACP school desegregation efforts have been established in all four cases, leading investigators to speculate that a white racist group may be responsible. After police defused a bomb at an NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla., Tuesday, the organization placed all its offices on alert. Four anonymous letters mailed in August to declare war on various federal appeals courts are being examined for clues to the bombings, FBI spokesman Greg Jones said today in Washington. St. Luke's Episcopal Church, in a quiet area of this wooded, exclusive suburb of Birmingham, was surrounded by police barriers as part of security precautions that included bomb searches and guards. Among those attending was Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy, who oversees Vance's appellate circuit. Vance's wife, Helen, remained hospitalized from wounds received in the bombing. Family friends said Vance's body had been cremated and his ashes will be placed in the church. In Baltimore today, NAACP executive director Benjamin Hooks said the attacks will not prevent the NAACP from ``moving forward full speed ahead on the job of trying to make America a place of equal justice for all.'' ``I think it's the work of white supremacists without any question. I think it reveals the derangement, demented, criminally stupid minds,'' Hooks said. Hooks said he had been assured by Sessions and Thornburgh that the bombings were being given the highest priority. William Hinshaw, agent in charge of the Atlanta FBI office, told The Birmingham News in an interview published today that the deadly package addressed to Vance was mailed Thursday from Newnan, a town of about 11,500 people 30 miles southwest of Atlanta. The bomb that killed Robinson on Monday is believed to have been mailed Friday from Macon, 82 miles southeast of Atlanta, Hinshaw said, but the postmark was destroyed in the blast. The Atlanta Constitution quoted unidentified sources as saying it bore a return address in Warner Robins, a town near Macon. The bomb found Tuesday in Jacksonville also was mailed Friday from Macon, Hinshaw said. A Jacksonville NAACP official, Lloyd N. Pearson, told the Macon Telegraph and News the package bore the return address of a Warner Robins lawyer. Another device was mailed Saturday from the Atlanta area to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals clerk's office in Atlanta, Hinshaw said, and the Constitution reported it bore the return address of an Atlanta lawyer. The court, on which Vance served, handled appeals of federal cases from Georgia, Alabama and Florida. That bomb was removed safely. All four bombs reportedly were designed to hurl nails or shrapnel. Sessions told reporters that some organized group could be responsible for the bombs. He said a pattern of racist attacks ``has to be one of the factors in the back of all our minds.'' ``Common sense would tell you _ the number of incidents ... in three different states, all part of the 11th Circuit. It's quite possible there is more than one (person responsible),'' Sessions said. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said he believed an organized group was behind the attacks. He instructed the civil rights group's 1,800 offices to take precautions in handling mail. Hooks also said he fears the bombings were the beginning of a wave of attacks: ``The thing has come to the place where everyone may be in jeopardy, from the president on down.'' One possible link between the cases was the NAACP's efforts to desegregate Southern schools, authorities said. Evidence included: _Vance wrote the 11th Circuit's unanimous opinion three months ago that ruled in favor of the NAACP in a desegregation suit against the Jacksonville, Fla., schools. _Robinson, a black city alderman, represented the NAACP in another desegregation case involving Savannah area schools. On Sept. 29, an 11th Circuit panel that didn't include Vance upheld a desegregation plan opposed by the NAACP. _The Jacksonsville NAACP chapter talked with Robinson about its desegregation case, but Robinson did not represent them. ``He gave us some advice,'' said the Rev. Fred Newbill, pastor of the First Timothy Baptist Church. Vance and Robinson shared a moderate-to-progressive political stance and an interest in civil rights, but friends of the two believed they had never met.
